meanings.defHTML: To hang or drape clothes on or around one's body.
To experience something bad, such as a loss, injury, damage, etc.
To be favored with or benefit by something.

examples.example: 나는 그들에게 입은 은혜를 절대로 잊을 수가 없다.
세금을 내리면 결국 혜택을 입는 사람은 서민들이다.

wordDefs.defHTML: To hang or drape clothes on or around one's body.
To experience something bad, such as a loss, injury, damage, etc.
To be favored with or benefit by something.

examples.example: 나는 그들에게 입은 은혜를 절대로 잊을 수가 없다.
세금을 내리면 결국 혜택을 입는 사람은 서민들이다.

matchingLog:
match try / have an experience  -어 보다  prio = 2.02 span= (6, 15) : 어:EC;보:VX
match Polite informal   -어요  prio = 1.02 span= (16, 21) : 아요:EF
match And / because  -아/어/여  prio = 1.02 span= (6, 10) : 어:EC
 * dropped, spanned by larger or superceded by a more-constrained pattern

patterns.sourceSample: 나는 건강을 위해 가벼운 운동이라도 매일 해 보려고 한다. 지수는 자전거를 한 번도 타 본 적이 없다. 손님, 그 원피스가 마음에 드시면 한번 입어 보세요.

relatedPatterns.patternDescr: I tried (and I found)  : ~ 아/어 보니까  (Clause-connecting form)

gr.defHTML:
-어 보다 has two meanings.


  • try doing something: indicating that one does the act mentioned in the preceding statement, as a test

e.g. 마음에 드시면 입어 보세요. (Try that on if you like it.)


  • have an experience of doing something : indicating that one experienced the act mentioned in the preceding statement earlier.

e.g. 제주도에 가 봤어요? (Have you ever been to Jeju Island?)


It has three forms.

-아 보다 combines with a verb whose stem has ㅏ/ㅗ as its last vowel.

-어 보다 combines with a verb whose stem has other vowels.

-여 보다 combines with verbs in -하다 form.

examples.example: 나는 건강을 위해 가벼운 운동이라도 매일 해 보려고 한다.

parts.start: 나는 건강을 위해 가벼운 운동이라도 매일

examples.translation: I try to do even light exercises every day for my health.

examples.example: 지수는 자전거를 한 번도 타 본 적이 없다.
examples.translation: Jisu has never ridden a bicycle before.
Try that on if you like it.
Have you ever been to Jeju Island?

gr.title: try / have an experience

patterns.sourceSample: 전화를 받아요. 양이 좀 적어요. 전화를 받았어요.

gr.defHTML:
-어요 is a polite informal ending. This sentence ending can be used for statements, questions, commands and proposals.


It has several forms.

-아요 combines with a verb or an adjective whose stem has ㅏ or ㅗ as its last vowel.

e.g. 날씨가 좋아요. (The weather is nice.)


-어요 combines with a verb or an adjective whose stem has other vowels.

e.g. 셔츠가 예뻐요. (The shirt looks pretty.)


-여요 combines with a verb or an adjective whose stem is in -하다 form.

e.g. 신발이 불편해요. (The shoes are not very comfortable.)


-에요 combines with -이다 / -아니다 verb.

e.g. 저는 학생이에요. (I am a student.)

e.g. 저는 학생이 아니에요. (I am not a student.)


-예요 combines with a noun which ends with a vowel.

e.g. 이 분은 우리 아빠예요. (This person is my dad.)

examples.translation: The shoes are not very comfortable.

gr.title: Polite informal
